entry.title: The New Explore Migration Objects App, The Game Changer in Planning Your Data Migration
entry.content:
A Short Trip to History

Since people have been performing data migrations into different systems, they have wanted to know the dependencies between the various data they need to migrate. They usually create project plans, PowerPoint presentations, or use tools like Visio to make these dependencies visible. As the saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. Since SAP began delivering preconfigured data migration objects, initially as a Rapid Deployment Solution for SAP ECC, later for SAP S/4HANA, and then as migration objects for the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit, customers have repeatedly asked for an overview diagram of the dependencies of these objects.

Initially, when the number of migration objects was manageable, there was an attempt to create an overview diagram in Visio. The interim result, shown in Figure 1, reflects only a portion of the objects present at that time. Each additional object made the diagram increasingly confusing.

The data initially resembled a sewing machine pattern or the London Tube Map, making it unusable.

Since the data was already in the system, the dependencies of a migration object were listed in the SAP Help Portal documentation. Customers could view them there. Later, this information was also included in the overview list of "Available Migration Objects."

There have always been efforts to provide customers with an interactive map. Initially, we considered displaying it on a web page using Python's network graph tool. However, this approach failed due to technical, hosting, and maintenance problems.

 

The Tile of Happiness

entry.title: Production Integration with Warehouse Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
The are many variations when it comes to production integration with Warehouse Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and it can sometimes seem difficult to find the right approach for your business scenario. This blog tries to put them all into context, equipping you with confidence to make the best decision for your use case. This blog assumes that you already have a basic understanding of the concepts and does not cover detailed step-by-step descriptions or master data settings as you can find those in the related scope items or online documentation, which are linked further down.

 

The Big Picture

The production integration process consists mainly of 3 +1 steps:

  1. Staging components to the production supply area (PSA)
  2. Consumption of the components
  3. Goods receipt from production
  4. Returning unused components back to the warehouse (optional)

For each of these steps, there are again different process variations which are described in detail below.

Please note, for the sake of simplicity I have only used the term production order below, but the statements are valid for process orders as well. Also, repetitive manufacturing is not covered in this blog post.

 

Staging of Components

Delivery-Based Staging (The Classical Approach)

Delivery-based staging to production is what I would call the classical approach. I am starting to explain this one first, not because I would recommend it the most, but because it helps to understand further concepts easier as they are built on top of it.

To activate this approach, you need to maintain the staging indicator in the control cycle to either 1 - Pick Parts or 3 - Release Order Parts. The pick parts strategy calculates the required staging quantity for components individually per production order and therefore creates one delivery per production order. The release order parts strategy calculates the required staging quantity across the components of all production orders selected for staging, thereby creating one joint delivery for all selected production orders. In any case, the calculated quantity will always be based on the total component quantity required per production orders, meaning the full required quantity will be requested for staging at once.

We need to distinguish between two different scenarios for the delivery-based approach which depend on the storage location of the PSA. If the storage location of the PSA is managed with Inventory Management (IM), then the outbound delivery from Delivery Management is replicated as an outbound delivery to Warehouse Management (WM). The staging warehouse tasks to the PSA are then created similarly to creating warehouse tasks to any outbound delivery, e.g. with the app Manage Outbound Delivery Orders. Once the staging is completed and the stock has been moved to the PSA, the outbound delivery must be posted goods issue, to move the stock to the IM storage location, from which the consumption of the components can take place afterwards. This process is described in scope item 3DV.

In the second variant of the delivery-based staging, the PSA is managed within WM in the same warehouse number, thus the outbound delivery from delivery management is replicated as a posting change to WM, since no goods issue posting is required in this case but only a movement within the warehouse. The staging warehouse tasks to the PSA are then created similarly to creating warehouse tasks to any posting change, e.g. with the app Process Posting Change Item. The products then remain on the PSA in WM and the consumption will be posted from there. This process is described in scope item 5HO.

To compare these two options, staging with the outbound delivery order seems a bit more complicated as the goods issue posting is required as an additional step to get the products to the PSA. In addition, returning not used components back to the warehouse is also more complicated as it must first be posted from the IM storage location back to the WM storage location. But there might also be good use cases for this approach, for example, if a company wants to strictly separate the responsibility of stock between logistics and production on a storage location level and production staff shall not even access Warehouse Management. It might be another use case to have the PSA at a different address and delivery papers must be printed for the transport.

 

Advanced Production Integration (The Textbook Approach)

The Advanced Production Integration, as described in scope item 6NI, is the most flexible approach and superior to the other approaches in many aspects. It is available since the 2302 release. The key object is the Production Material Request (PMR) which is basically a reflection of the production order, containing the attributes relevant for the warehouse process. It is created once the function WM Material Staging is carried out for the production order. The prerequisite for the PMR to be created is to set the staging indicator 5 (EWM Staging) on the respective control cycle.

Before the actual staging can happen, settings are required in the app Assign Bin to PSA to control how the staging proposals shall be created. This is where the main differentiation to the other staging processes lies.

You can define the following staging method to be used:

  • Not Relevant for Staging: The product does not need to be staged but will be consumed. This could, for example, be silo material.
  • Cross Order Staging: The system will calculate the required quantity across all PMR items selected for staging. The staged components can then be consumed by any production order.
  • Single Order Staging: The quantities are calculated, and the staging warehouse tasks are created for each selected PMR item individually. The warehouse task and after, confirmation of the warehouse task, also the stock will have a reference to this PMR, thereby ensuring that it can be consumed for that specific PMR only.

Figure 1 - App Assign Bin to PSA

 You can also define how the staging quantity shall be calculated:

  • No Quantity Calculation: The staging quantity must be entered manually
  • Quantity-Based Calculation: The staging quantity is calculated based on the fields Replenishment Quantity and Minimum Product Quantity in PSA in the same table. Only if the stock level of the product at the PSA (including open warehouse tasks to the PSA) is below the minimum quantity, is a staging warehouse task created for the defined replenishment quantity.
  • Calculation Based on PMRs: The staging quantity is defined by the exact quantity requested for the component in the PMR.

Now what is so special about this? The option for Single Order Staging is available exclusively for the Advanced Production Integration. If you want to make sure that the stock to be staged will be reserved for that production order, then this is the way to go. Also, the Quantity-Based Calculation is exclusive to the Advanced Production Integration, and it allows you to continuously stage the required components, respecting potential capacity limitations of the PSA. But you still have the full flexibility: If you want to stage across all orders (Cross-Order Staging) and / or always stage the full required quantity at once (Calculation Based on PMRs), then this is also available with the PMR based quantity calculation. In my experience, most typically would the Cross Order Staging be combined with the Quantity-Based Calculation and the Single-Order Staging with the Calculation based on PMRs, but also other combinations are possible.

As it might be necessary to maintain these settings for many products, you can also upload these settings using the respective migration object. These settings are necessary, because you may want to define different staging behaviors and different quantities to be staged for different products. If, however, your requirement for the quantity calculation is rather simple and you just want to always stage the full required component quantity at once, then you can also define just one wildcard entry by leaving the product field empty and maintain for this entry the Calculation Based on PMRs. In this case, the system will then calculate for any product to always stage to full required quantity at once.

Once these settings have been made, the actual staging can start. For this, multiple apps are available which are also exclusive to the Advanced Production Integration.

The app Stage for Production is a staging cockpit for the Warehouse Clerk. There are multiple selection criteria available to define what shall be staged, e.g. by PSA, product or production order. Based on this selection, staging proposals are calculated and displayed to the user. The user can then decide to create a staging warehouse task for the proposed quantity or to manually overwrite it before creating the warehouse task. While the system supports the user by providing an overview on what needs to be staged and calculates staging proposals, the final decision is with the user.

Figure 2 - App Stage for Production

Alternatively, the staging can also be fully automated with the app Schedule Staging for Production by specifying the relevant parameters and scheduling it in background. For example, you could schedule that for a certain PSA, staging warehouse task are always created two hours before they are expected at the PSA.

Figure 3 - App Schedule Staging for Production

The same application can also be started in foreground with the app Create Warehouse Tasks - Staging for Production which will show immediate feedback by displaying a log on the selection and calculation results.

Comparison to Delivery-Based Staging

Let’s compare the delivery-based staging with the Advanced Production Integration:

The differentiation between Pick Parts and Release Order Parts in the delivery-based staging is somewhat similar to the staging methods Single Order Staging and Cross Order Staging of the PMR when combined with the quantity calculation type Calculation based on PMRs, but there are two main differences: For the delivery-based staging, the quantity calculation already takes place during the delivery creation, while for the PMR the quantity is calculated during the warehouse task creation. Also, the Pick Parts strategy does not lead to any document reference in the picking warehouse task or the picked stock, in contrast to the Single Order Staging. Therefore, when using Pick Parts, the system cannot ensure that this stock would be reserved for the production order it had initially been staged for.

In addition, while for the delivery-based staging the delivery is always created for the full quantity of the requested components, the Advanced Production Integration can offer a more flexible, continuous approach to determining the staging quantity with the Quantity Based Calculation. Moreover, there are additional apps available such as Stage for Production which can calculate those quantity proposals and thereby provide a good overview to the warehouse clerk on what needs to be staged.

The advantage of the delivery-based staging might be, that it works similarly to the classical outbound to customer process and can therefore be perceived as the easier approach by end users as they are used to this process already, working with outbound delivery orders or posting change items. In addition, only the delivery-based staging allows to stage quantities to a separate storage location outside of the current warehouse number.

Details on the Quantity Calculation

The details on the quantity calculation can require some explanation to understand the overall concept and idea behind it.

Quantity Based Calculation:
The quantity-based calculation has been built with the intent, not to stage the full required quantity of a component at once but to continuously stage over time, in order not to exceed the PSA capacity. In addition, it has been designed for production orders where the required quantity of components is not necessarily known exactly up-front but can vary. Examples for this would be the food industry, in contrast to industrial manufacturing. Therefore, the quantity of the staging warehouse task is not calculated based on the quantity of the PMR item, but taken from the quantity maintained as Replenishment Quantity in the app Assing Bin to PSA.

Now, when is staging proposed at all? Staging is proposed for a component, when the quantity of that product on the PSA (+ open warehouse tasks) is below the quantity maintained as Minimum Product Quantity in PSA. It is important to note, that this is independent of the component quantity of the PMR item. Even if there is theoretically no open quantity, because there is already equally or even more stock on the PSA than the component quantity, staging will still be proposed if the stock level for that product is below the Minimum Product Quantity in PSA. That is based on the idea explained above, that in certain industries the quantities maintained in the bill of material are not necessarily 100% accurate and it is more important to ensure there is always sufficient stock on the PSA than to worry about having to return some of the components later. Therefore, it is not a good idea to leave the field Minimum Product Quantity in PSA empty or to maintain an unrealistically high value, since this will lead to infinite staging for that product!

Even though the staging quantities are mainly based on the entries in the app Assing Bin to PSA, staging is proposed for a product if there are any relevant (= not yet technically completed) PMR items for that product. This is true for cross-order as well as for single-order staging. For single-order staging, the whole calculation logic is anyway done separately per PMR, to ensure there is sufficient stock with the respective PMR reference on the PSA.

Calculation Based on PMRs:

The calculation based on PMR has been built to cover the opposite use case, more common in e.g. industrial manufacturing, to always stage exactly the full quantity required for a component at once. It is basically the case which can also be covered with the delivery-based staging. In this case, the quantity to stage is calculated as the open required quantity by taking the component quantity as defined in the PMR items and subtracting from it already consumed quantity, quantity on the PSA and open warehouse tasks quantity pointing to the PSA. With that, exactly the remaining required quantity as it has been defined in the bill of material is planned to be staged. This works with cross order staging as well as single-order staging. In addition, the Minimum Product Quantity in PSA can be used to define the maximum quantity for the product at the PSA. This is again to ensure, the maximum capacity of the PSA can be considered when staging. Any staging quantity that has been calculated will be checked and potentially reduced, to make sure it does not exceed that quantity. For this calculation, the stock already on the PSA as well as open warehouse tasks are considered.

 

Manual Staging (The Simple Approach)

In the end, the required products must be moved to the PSA somehow, to make them available for the production clerk. All methods mentioned above shall help the users to determine which components shall be staged at which time and in which quantity. But if the warehouse and production operations are rather simple, there is also no harm in just manually moving the components to the production supply area by creating ad-hoc warehouse tasks. These can either be created with the app Create Product Warehouse Tasks or Create HU Warehouse Tasks from the desktop, or from a mobile device with the respective RF transactions.

 

Staging via API (The Developer Approach)

Often manufacturing execution systems are used in production and thus the staging warehouse tasks must be created from an external system via APIs. In such scenarios, the manufacturing execution system might calculate the required quantities for the PSA and can then use the Warehouse Order and Task API to create the warehouse task by specifying the required product, quantity and the destination bin for the PSA. Please see this roadmap item which describes the option to specify the PMR item as parameter to create single order staging warehouse tasks as well.

 

Kanban (The Pull Approach)

The Kanban process is a special approach to staging which differs from the others discussed so far, since in this case the operator at the PSA can request the supply by setting the Kanban container to empty. Usually, it is a pure business decision whether the production shall be supplied by Kanban or not. However, if the decision was taken to use the Kanban approach, then this is fully integrated with Warehouse Management. Once the Kanban container has been set to empty (e.g. with the app Set Kanban Container Status), then a warehouse task is created immediately to stage the products to the production supply area. Once that warehouse task has been confirmed, the Kanban is again set to full. This process is also described in scope item 3VT.

 

No Staging (The Minimalistic Approach)

From a physical point of view, the products must of course be moved to the production supply area. But some customers even go for a very minimalistic approach, not to reflect the staging in the system at all. Instead, from a system perspective, the stock is consumed directly from the storage bin in the warehouse itself. This can be achieved with the app Post Goods Movement which even offers a button (right next to the storage bin field) to trigger the stock removal strategy to determine the most suitable stock item for consumption.

Figure 4 - App Post Goods Movement

Some customers then trigger the printing of a material document slip based on that material document with output management, as the storage bin can be printed on there so the warehouse clerk can take that slip to find the right bin in the warehouse to physically retrieve the stock and move it to the production line.

 

Consumption of Components

Consumption via Post Consumption - Production App

The app Post Consumption – Production is only available when working with the Advanced Production Integration. The user first enters the manufacturing order number and is then displayed with the stock available for consumption at the production supply area of the related PMR. The user can then choose to perform consumption postings or to reverse them. To consume the stock, the stock must fit exactly to the stock criteria of the PMR, for example it must match the exact stock type or potentially batch if a specific batch has been requested and of course the correct PMR reference if it is single order stock. This app provides a very clear overview on what is available for consumption and offers a very controlled way of ensuring that only the right stock, which has been properly staged, is consumed.

Figure 5 - App Post Consumption

 

Consumption via a Mobile Handheld Device

The consumption as well as the reversal of components for a manufacturing order can also be processed on a mobile handheld device, using the Post Consumption for Production transaction in RF.  Here, the user first enters the manufacturing order to work on, to then specify the stock that shall be consumed. This functionality is only available when working with the Advanced Production Integration.

Figure 6 - RF Environment 

 

Consumption via Post Goods Movement App

The app Post Goods Movement can also be used for an explicit consumption posting. When the storage location entered is WM relevant, the additional tab Warehouse Management is displayed. With this, the user can specify the storage bin to consume from, usually the storage bin of the PSA. The storage bin for consumption is automatically proposed from the storage bin maintained in the control cycle.  It is also possible to specify the handling unit to consume from.

Figure 7 - App Post Goods Movement 

 

Consumption via Backflush

If no explicit consumption posting is necessary, then the stock can also be consumed via backflush, meaning the stock is consumed automatically according to the bill of material upon confirmation of the production order (operation). Backflush is supported with Warehouse Management, independent of the staging method. It also works for single-order staging items and is supported in various apps in discrete and repetitive manufacturing such as Confirm Production Operation, Reprocess Goods Movements and Confirm Repetitive Manufacturing. For a full list of supported apps, please see here.

Consumption via API

The consumption can also be posted via API, for example with one of the following APIs:

  • Material Documents API
  • Production Order Confirmation API
  • Process Order Confirmation API

All these APIs offer the fields EWMWarehouse and EWMStorageBin which must be used to post the consumption in Warehouse Management. For some it is also possible to specify the HandlingUnitExternalID for consumption.

 

Goods Receipt from Production

Direct Goods Receipt Posting via Post Goods Movement App

The goods receipt for the finished product can also be posted with the app Post Goods Movement with a direct goods receipt posting. The app allows the user to specify the stock that shall be posted goods receipt and the storage bin for this posting. The user can also pack the product into handling units.

Figure 8 - App Post Goods Movement

The goods receipt storage bin is automatically proposed, based on the storage bin maintained in the production version (Destination Bin).

Figure 9 - App Process Production Versions

 The packing can be proposed automatically as well in case packing instructions have been maintained. Additionally, the putaway warehouse task can be created automatically upon goods receipt posting by setting the field Process Type Setting for Automatic WT Creation at GR in the SSCUI Define Warehouse Process Type to Active.

 

Figure 10 - SSCUI Define Warehouse Process Type

 This process of the direct goods movement posting is only available, if activated in the SSCUI Define Production Scheduling Profile for Discrete Manufacturing (102508) or Define Production Scheduling Profile for Process Manufacturing (102814) respectively, by setting the value for Post Synchronously to Bin to 3 - Goods Receipt and Goods Issue. If the value is set to 2 - Only Goods Issue instead, the direct goods movement postings are not available, and an inbound delivery is created. 

 

 

Direct Goods Receipt via Further Apps

In addition to the Post Goods Movement app, the direct goods receipt can also be posted with the app Post Goods Receipt for Production Order or the app Enter Goods Receipt for Handling Units to post goods receipt on a handling unit basis.

 

Automatic Goods Receipt Posting

Instead of manually posting the goods receipt, the goods receipt posting can also be automated upon confirmation of the production order. This can also be activated in the SSCUI Define Production Scheduling Profile for Discrete Manufacturing (102508) or Define Production Scheduling Profile for Process Manufacturing (102814) respectively, by setting the flag for Automatic Goods Receipt.

 

This is a very popular approach, especially in combination with the automatic warehouse task creation because it provides a very lean process: Upon confirmation of the production order, the goods receipt is posted directly to the storage bin in Warehouse Management and the putaway task can be created automatically if configured for the warehouse process type. And recently, with 2508.3, also the feature to support automatic packing (which can be activated in SSCUI Define Production Scheduling Profile with field Automatic Packing in Sync. Goods Receipt to Bin t) in this scenario has been delivered.

 

Goods Receipt via Inbound Delivery

As described in the previous chapters, the direct goods receipt postings are only active depending on the settings in the production scheduling profile. The setting can also be changed to using inbound deliveries. The inbound delivery would then be created upon triggering the goods receipt as described in the previous chapters – either explicitly (via Post Goods Movement apps or others) or implicitly with the automatic goods receipt posting. In other words, triggering the goods receipt posting does not yet actually post goods receipt, but only creates the inbound delivery which then again must be posted goods receipt in a second step. This may sound unnecessarily complex, and one could agree to that impression. Usually, going for the direct goods receipt posting is the leaner and thereby simpler process. However, inbound deliveries also offer some advantages in terms of flexibility, as the following is only available with inbound deliveries:

  • Flexible determination of the warehouse process type with SSCUI Determine Warehouse Process Type (104392)
  • Flexible determination of storage bin for goods receipt with the app Determine Staging Area - Inbound

 

Goods Receipt Posting via API

Goods receipt can also be posted via the following APIs which is especially useful when integrating with an external MES:

  • Material Documents API
  • Action PostDiscreteMfgGoodsReceipt of the Handling Unit API
    • Requires up-front packing e.g. with action PackDiscreteMfgAutomatically of the Handling Unit API

 

Special Processes in Goods Receipt

Some special processes in the goods receipt process that are independent of the method of goods receipt are also worth mentioning:

In general, an integration to quality management is supported. Details on how to set this up are described in scope item 3M0 and in the SAP Help Portal.

While often the focus is on the goods receipt for main products, it is important to mention that goods receipt posting is also supported for co-products and by-products.

 

Return Unused Components Back to the Warehouse

Especially when working with the quantity-based calculation based on PMRs, more components may have been staged than what has been required ultimately. In this case, it may be a requirement to return those back to the warehouse and clear the production supply area. To return them, ad-hoc warehouse tasks must be created. These can either be created with the app Create Product Warehouse Tasks or Create HU Warehouse Tasks from the Desktop, or from a mobile device with the respective RF transactions. In addition, when working with the Advanced Production Integration, the app Clear Production Supply Areas is meant for exactly this purpose. It allows the user to select stock which currently sits at the production supply area and to create warehouse tasks to return them back to the warehouse. In addition, for single-order staging products, the PMR reference can be removed.

Figure 11 - Fiori App Clear Production Supply Area

 

Conclusion

This blog tried to outline that there are many aspects to consider when it comes to production integration. The Advanced Production Integration certainly offers the most flexible approach, while the delivery-based staging may be easier for some end users as it is similar to classical outbound processes. Kanban, which is based on a completely different concept, is also supported, but also manual staging may be an option. Also, for the consumption parts there are different options to post it explicitly via various apps or implicitly via backflush. The goods receipt from production can also be posted explicitly with multiple apps or implicitly upon production order confirmation. In addition, staging, consumption, and goods receipt can all be called via API, offering the full flexibility with external software or side-by-side extensions.

Which of those options is best fit for your project, depends largely on your use case. Hopefully, the information provided in this blog, can help you in taking that decision.

entry.title: ASM Product Categories in Spartacus
entry.content:
In this blog, we will learn how you can create a special product category that is available to ASM agents only in Spartacus. This category can be used to include special items that normal users would not have access to, enabling ASM agents to offer unique items to their customers.

Pre-requisite  – Before starting the implementation. I assume that you have already installed the latest SAP Commerce with Spartacus sample data

The procedure for setting up ASM categories involves five main steps:

  1. Create a new category
  2. Create a Navigation Node related to the category
  3. Add items to the category
  4. Restrict search results
  5. Test the setup

Create a new category

Set up a new ASM category. For the specific creation steps, please refer to https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_CLOUD_PUBLIC_CLOUD/aa417173fe4a4ba5a473c93eb730a417/26af97b95a384d08af4f6d23bd62fc9f.html?q=categories for more details.

Additional details

  1. Identifier: recommended value 1500
  2. Name: ASM Category
  3. Catalog Version: Powertools Product Catalog
  4. Supercategories: Open Catalogue [1] - Powertools Product Catalog

This completes the required setup for creating the category.

Create a Navigation Node related to the category

Add a menu item with an entry to the navigation tree.

For detailed steps, refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_CLOUD_PUBLIC_CLOUD/8d5b806fe6a44da681c9df6edc6f6971/25b673e3876343709956a61bc565b332.html

Additional details

  1. Create Menu Item

    Create a child node under the Categories navigation node.

  2. Create Entry

    Add an entry for the new menu item.

  3. Create Component

    • Choose Component Link
    • Select URL Link for the Link type, Set the URL to:/Open-Catalogue/c/1500(Ensure 1500matches the Identifier used when creating the category.)
    • Display Rule:
      • Display Rule (Restriction) Type: Usergroup Restriction
      • Create a rule (e.g., asm display rule)
      • User Groups: Customer Manager Group

Add items to the category

Next, add the required products to the ASM category. Refer to https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_CLOUD_PUBLIC_CLOUD/aa417173fe4a4ba5a473c93eb730a417/025fae2433b949b8af33734476a2566e.html?q=product+category+system for more details.

Restrict search results

Restrict the visibility of items in the ASM category so they appear only to ASM agents.

Refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_COMMERCE_CLOUD_PUBLIC_CLOUD/9b5366ff6eb34df5be29881ff55f97d2/9730791651d94f55a7b21a85348828b6.html?q=visibility

Additional details

Please pay attention to the following key points when performing the procedures described in the guide:

  1. Setting Visibility Based on Category in Backoffice
    • Step 4: Select the ASM category created earlier (1500, ASM Category).
    • Step 5: Add customermanagergroup and anonymous to the visibility restriction.
  2. Configuring Indexed Field and Running Full Index Cronjob
    • Step 2: Select powertoolsProductType
    • Step 10: Select powertoolsindex
  3. Enabling Search Restriction in Backoffice
    • Modify Frontend_RestrictedCategory as shown in the documentation.
    • Apply the same configuration to Frontend_Assignment*(Restricted Type = Product)*
    • When running the full index, select powertoolsindex
  4. Optional
    • Enhancing Update Indexed Query is optional and may be skipped.

Test the setup

Finally, test your setup to ensure it works as expected.

  1. Navigate to the storefront with ASM enabled: https://localhost:4200/powertools-spa/en/USD/login?asm=true
  2. Log in as an ASM agent (use the asagent username and its password). The ASM link should appear to the right of all the other categories.
  3. Click the ASM link. Any items added to the ASM category should appear in the product list.
  4. Sign out as the ASM agent. The ASM link should not appear in the list of categories, and any item that is exclusive to the ASM category should not appear in search results

entry.title: 【SAPパートナー必見】TDD AI Unitがリリース！低価格でAI検証が可能に
entry.content:
ついに、皆様待望の新 TDD AI Unit の提供が始まりました。
このブログでは、SAPが最近リリースした新しい TDD AI Unit SKU について、 @finn_backer さんのブログの内容を翻訳し情報をまとめたいと思います。

まず、このTDD AI Unit提供は、パートナーの皆様にとって嬉しい点がいくつかあります。
①価格が本番用（productive）AI Unitsよりかなり抑えられている こと。
AI機能を使用するたびに SAP には LLM コストが発生するため、TDD向けとはいえSAPが一定の費用を請求する必要があります。
しかし、本番用のAI Unitと比較すると、TDDの価格は大幅に低く、SAPがAI活用、提案を本気で加速していきたい意図が現れています。

②基本的な仕組みが本番用AI Unitとほとんど同じであること。
唯一、契約期間が四半期ごと（3ヶ月）である点 は少し複雑さを増しますが、その分ライセンスも四半期ごとに解約できるなど、柔軟性をもたらしている側面もあります。

下記より、よくある質問をまとめる形式でご説明していきます。

Q. TDD AI Unit の価格はいくらですか？

簡単に説明すると、最小購入単位は100ユニット（1ブロック）で、価格は65ユーロです。
1ユーロ＝180円換算で、約11,700円弱になります。割引はなく、上限もありません。

契約期間が四半期（3か月）なので、見方を変えると、

25 AI Unitを 16.25ユーロ (約 2,900円) で買い、3ヶ月以内に使い切る契約（自動更新あり）

と表現することもできます。

Q. 今回のリリース内容と、その重要性は？

SAPパートナーにとって、AI機能をお客様にデモをしていくことは「Business Suite & AI First」の世界では極めて重要です。

これまでは、パートナーは一時的な措置として 本番用（productive）AI Units をTDD用途に流用していましたが、今回の新しい TDD AI Unit SKU により、主に次の2点が大きく改善されました。

  1. パートナーがセルフサービスでTDD AI Unitを購入できるようになった
    • SAP担当営業への問い合わせが不要となり、見積依頼、日程調整パートナーアカウントに正しくAI Unitが割り当てられるまでの手間も削減でき、時間的な遅延が大きく解消されます。
  2. 価格が本番用AI Unitライセンスより大幅に低い
    • デモ用途としてより利用しやすくなります。

Q. 通常の「Manage my services」アプリでTDDライセンスと同じように注文するの？

いいえ、異なります。TDD AI Unit は SAP Store 経由でのみ注文可能 です。SAPは今後、顧客およびパートナー向けの購入フローをSAP Storeへ集約していく方針で、今回のTDD AI Unitはその象徴的な例になっています。

SAP Store のAI Unit購入ページへアクセス、

  1. ページをスクロール
  2. “Buy as a partner” タブを選択
  3. “Configure to see price” をクリック
  4. SKU 8019670を購入

という流れで購入します。

Q. SAP Store の説明文に「年間100 Unitのブロックで、契約期間3ヶ月につき25%が割り当てられる、利用しないものは失効する」とあるが、本番のAI Unitと異なるのですか？

はい、その通りです。TDDの場合は、本番用AI Unitsとは少し仕組みが異なります。

TDDサブスクリプションでは、SAPは3か月を標準の契約期間としており、これはパートナーが商談サイクルに応じて、必要に応じて柔軟にシステムをオン／オフできるようにするためです。

その他の点については、TDD AI Units のルールは本番用AI Unitsと同様です。
具体的には：

  • ユーザーごとの「リクエスト」キャパシティ
  • 各AI機能ごとの「リクエスト」消費量（コスト）

などは本番AI Unitと同じです。
これらは全て、 TDD AI Features Guide Price List に記載されている内容に準拠します。

また、AI機能のアクティベーションプロセスについても、本番環境向けAI Unitsの場合とほぼ同じ手順となります。

Q. 解約したい場合はどうなりますか？

たとえば、パートナーが2026年1月1日に 100 AIユニット（1ブロック） を購入したとします。
購入時点で 16.25ユーロが請求され、25 AIユニット が付与されます（※年間100ユニットの25%）。

その後、パートナーが 契約終了日の30日前に解約を行った場合（＝3か月契約の終了前）、それ以上の請求は発生しません。

つまり、16.25ユーロを支払い、3か月間で25 AIユニットを使える
ということになります。

一方で、解約を行わなかった場合は、契約が自動更新され、
再び 16.25ユーロが請求され、次の3か月分として25 AIユニットが付与 されます。

Q. この新しい TDD AI Unit SKU を Joule for Consultant で使うことはできますか？

いいえ、できません。Joule for Consultant を利用するためには、本番用（productive）AI Units が必要です。
詳細はこちらをご覧ください。

Q. 100 AI Units（1ブロック）で何ができますか？

すでに TDD 上で Core ERP Cloud（Public） のLOBシステムを利用している場合、100ユニットを使って Financial Management AI の PUPM（Per User Per Month）ユーザーを1名、1年間運用できます。

  • Financial Management AI の月額コスト：8 AI Units / 月
  • 四半期ごとに必要なユニット：24 AI Units（8 × 3）
  • 年間必要ユニット：96 AI Units
    → 100 Units の1ブロックで1年間カバーできます。

Private Cloud、SCM、CX の場合も同様の計算方法です。

SuccessFactors の場合、

  • HCM AI の PUPM：0.5 AI Unit / 月
    → 100 AI Units で 16名のユーザーを1年間運用可能です。

※すべて TDD AI Features Guide Price List のデータに基づきます。

Q. Financial Management PUPM：四半期ごとに使い切れなかった1ユニットはどうなりますか？

使用しなかった AI Unit は 3ヶ月後に失効します（繰越不可）。
ただし、余った 1 Unit を有効活用するおすすめの方法をご紹介します。

💡おすすめ：Document Grounding
四半期あたり 0.6 AI Units で 40ドキュメント を処理可能
→ デモ用途には十分な容量です。

「Document Grounding: A hidden gem in SAP Business AI’s portfolio for smaller companies」の記事で詳細を確認いただけます。

Q. TDD ではユーザー名ではなく「ロールユーザー」でログインしますが、これは変わりますか？

いいえ、今まで通りです。

TDD で LOB ソリューションをデモする際にロール用ユーザーでログインするという運用は継続されます。

ただし、Cloud Identity Service 上で実際にログインに使うユーザー名に対して、AI PUPM パッケージを割り当てる必要があります。

Q. TDD AI Units を注文した後、AI機能を有効化するには何をすればいいですか？

LOBごとに多少異なります。詳細はこちらをご覧ください。
一般的なプロセスは以下の通りです：

  1. SAP for Me で、利用したい TDD PUPM パッケージのアクティベーションを申請
  2. Cloud Identity Services で、対象ユーザーに PUPM パッケージを割り当て
  3. SAP for Me で、利用したい AI Features のアクティベーションを申請
    • どの TDD インスタンスに紐づけるか指定
    • SAP がエンタイトルメントを LOB ソリューションへ付与
  4. LOB ソリューション内で、
    • ユーザーに対して個別の AI 機能利用権限を付与

Q. パートナーが 容量（request capacity）を使い過ぎる可能性はありますか？

各 AI PUPM ユーザーには非常に大きな request 容量（例：Financial PUPM で 5,200 request）が提供されます。

理論上、過剰利用は可能ですが、実際に起こる可能性は非常に低いです。

理由：

  • SAP は「本番利用でも十分余裕がある」ように request 容量を設計している
  • TDD では本番より AI 機能使用頻度が低いため、消費量も少ない
  • 仮に1ユーザーが多少使い過ぎても、他ユーザーの未使用分で相殺されるケースが多い

Q. 万が一パートナーとして “過剰利用（overuse）” した場合はどうなりますか？

もし過剰利用が発生した場合、追加で使用した分は、既存の AI Unit 残高から差し引かれます。

例えば : 

  • ERP Cloud で 5名の TDD AI PUPM ユーザーがいるとします
  • 月額費用は 26ユーロ
    • 計算：5ユーザー × 8 AI Units（PUPM）× 0.65ユーロ

ここで、仮に 全ユーザーが25% 過剰利用したとしましょう（実際は極めて起こりにくいですが）。
この場合、追加使用量は 13 AI Units、コストにすると 8.45ユーロ です。

計算の詳細（TDD AI Feature Guide Price List に基づく）

  1. 5ユーザーの合計リクエスト許容量
    5 × 5200 = 26,000 request
  2. 25%の過剰利用量
    26,000 × 25% = 6,500 request
  3. 超過分のAI Unit換算
    • 超過分1,000 request につき 2 AI Units
      → (6,500 / 1,000) × 2 = 13 AI Units
  4. AI Unit の金額換算
    13 AI Units × 0.65ユーロ = 8.45ユーロ

ただし、この金額（8.45ユーロ = 約1,500円）は、他のライセンスと比べ、かなりインパクトは小さいかと思います。

Q. 過剰利用が起こる可能性は非常に低く、費用インパクトも小さいとしても、どのように監視・管理すればよいですか？

SAPは 2026年Q1に SAP for Me 上で TDD AI Units の残高や消費状況を確認できる機能を提供する予定です。
パートナーは、これを定期的にチェックすることで利用状況を把握できます。

また、PUPMパッケージは 毎月 AI Units を消費する仕組みなので、ユーザーを月単位で「有効化／無効化」できます。

例えば：

もし12月時点で「しばらくAI機能を使わないコンサルタント」がいる場合、
12月末までに SAP Identity Cloud Services でそのユーザーのPUPMパッケージを無効化できます。
そうすると、1月以降はそのユーザーによるAI Units の消費はゼロになります。

毎月初め、SAPは

  • 前月にPUPMパッケージが割り当てられていたユーザー数
  • × 月ごとのAI Unitコスト
    を計算し、その分をAI Unit残高から差し引きます。

パートナー側でユーザー管理を行い、ユーザー1人あたりの月額AI Unit消費量も事前に分かっているため、消費量を自分たちでコントロールし、予測することが可能です。

Q. その他の質問は？

ゴールド／プラチナパートナーは、 SAP Business AI Licensing & Pricing Advisory を無料で利用できます。その他、こちらのブログに質問をいただくことも可能です。

TDD AI Unitに関連するAIコストの仕組みをさらに理解したい場合には、
「SAP PUPM Business AI: what does it cost to run ONE AI feature ONE time?」
を読むことをおすすめします（本番AI Unit向けの記事ですが、TDDでも共通点が多いです）。

SAP Business AI TDD全般については
Partner TDD landing page を参照してください。

では早速Business AIの検証を始めてみましょう！
Thank you @finn_backer -san!

entry.title: Re: Reflection of Offset Amount in the Closing Invoice
entry.content:
In SAP, the standard closing billing statement  typically shows only the net receivable amount after offsetting, because the purpose is to present what the customer owes after clearing mutual payables. However, if your business requirement is to display both the original receivable and the offset payable amounts, then please note that there is no standard setting to show both the amounts.
You need a custom logic form (smart form/adobe form ) to do so.
Option 1
Use Output Management / Smart Forms / Adobe Forms for the billing statement.
Include:
Original Receivable Amount
Offset Payable Amount
Net Amount to be billed
This also requires adding fields from the clearing document or related AP items to the form logic.
Option 2
Instead of modifying the billing statement, you can generate a custom correspondence that lists both AR and AP items for transparency. This is used in Japan 
In SAP Financial Accounting, a correspondence type refers to a predefined category of communication or document that you send to customers, vendors, or internal stakeholders.
 
Configuration Steps
Define Correspondence Type in FI (transaction OB77).
Assign program and form (Smart Form or Adobe Form).
Use BAdI FI_CORR_PRINT or SD billing output enhancement to pull payable data.

entry.title: Ready, Set, Go! Jump-start complex Collaboration Scenarios with Start Forms
entry.content:
Manually creating Collaborations in SAP Integrated Product Development (IPD) often requires several steps: creating the Collaboration itself, adding Reference Objects and Participants, starting Workflows, and more. Public APIs let you automate these steps. By invoking those APIs from a Process in SAP Build Process Automation - triggered by a Start Form - you can deliver an app-like experience to users inside SAP Build Work Zone.

This post shows how to provide dedicated Start Form apps for common IPD Collaboration scenarios. The main steps are:

  • Configure the Collaboration Type.
  • Design the Process and Start Form.
  • Add the Start Form to SAP Build Work Zone.

Configure the Collaboration Type

Create a Collaboration Type that maps to your business needs. Define a Status Profile, add Reference Objects, and attach Workflows. Using APIs to create Collaborations imposes no extra requirements.

Configure Collaboration

 

Design the Process and Start Form

Make sure that you have imported all required Actions for SAP Integrated Product Development Collaboration from SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Create a new Process in SAP Build Process Automation and design a Form as Trigger for the Process.

Start Form Designer

Add the Actions you need based on the Collaboration properties you want to set. In our example:

  1. Create a new Collaboration.
  2. Add a Participant.
  3. Add a Reference Object.
  4. Optionally start a Workflow (based on a user choice).

There are no tasks that require user interaction in this example. Of course, you can use all features provided by SAP Build Process Automation.

Process Design

Add Start Form to SAP Build Work Zone

Create a local copy of the Process Trigger App and provide the Launchpad Configuration Parameters of your deployed Process. Add this to your site and apply the required authorizations. The form will become visible as separate tile.

Start Form in SAP Build Work Zone

When users click the tile, the Start Form appears. 

Start Form

After they complete required fields and submit, the Process invokes the APIs to create the Collaboration, add the Reference Object and Participant, and start the Workflow if requested. The collaboration is ready within seconds and contains all necessary data for users to begin work.

Ready to use Collaboration

Summary

Start Forms are an efficient way to expose frequently used Collaboration setups to end users. By leveraging custom Processes, you can enrich user input with external data, add validations, and improve data quality and the overall experience - enabling smoother, faster collaboration.

1. Summary

 

In this blog series, we shared our hands-on experience from multiple SAP EHS Public Cloud projects that were implemented in a hybrid, side-by-side landscape. Across Parts 1 to 5, we covered the integration of Employees, Business Partners, Materials, Functional Locations, and Equipment, as well as practical extensibility scenarios from real customer use cases.

What became very clear throughout these projects is that SAP EHS Public Cloud works best when three things come together:

  • Consistent master data,
  • Standardized integration content,
  • And a disciplined clean-core extensibility strategy.

In practice, we saw that missing or inconsistent master data was the most common root cause for broken end-to-end EHS processes (far more critical than any technical limitation). Once HR data, business partners, materials and assets were properly aligned across systems, incident reporting, emissions calculations, and follow-up processes became significantly more stable and transparent.

Another key learning was that standard communication scenarios and scope items save a tremendous amount of time and risk. Whenever we were able to rely on delivered content instead of custom interfaces, implementation effort, testing effort, and long-term maintenance were reduced noticeably.

Finally, extensibility played an important role in every single project. While most requirements could be solved using in-app Key User Extensibility, it was essential to define clear governance early on to avoid country-specific deviations and long-term technical debt.

This final part summarizes the key benefits and pitfalls we repeatedly encountered and shares our outlook on how SAP EHS in the Public Cloud will continue to evolve based on what we see today in real projects.

 

2. Benefits & Pitfalls

Integrating SAP EHS as part of a hybrid SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud landscape delivers strong business value but it also introduces architectural and organizational challenges that need to be managed carefully. In this chapter, we summarize the most important benefits and pitfalls we encountered across different customer projects.

2.1 Benefits

Fast Access to Innovation through Public Cloud Releases & AI

One of the strongest benefits we experienced in our projects was the direct access to new EHS functionality without classical upgrade projects. Unlike on-premise systems with long release cycles, customers benefit immediately from:

  • Regular Public Cloud releases and micro deliveries
  • Fast availability of new EHS features and regulatory content
  • Immediate access to SAP’s latest AI-driven innovations in EHS scenarios

This had a noticeable impact on time-to-value. Instead of waiting months for technical upgrades, functional improvements became available continuously. For several customers, this was also the first time AI-supported features in the EHS context could be evaluated productively.

Data Consistency and Compliance

A unified master data landscape turned out to be one of the biggest success factors across all projects. By integrating:

  • Employee data from SAP SuccessFactors
  • Business Partners & Materials from SAP MDG
  • Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

We ensured that EHS processes consistently relied on harmonized and validated master data. In practice, this was essential for:

  • Accurate incident reporting,
  • Reliable emissions calculations,
  • Correct assignment of responsibilities and workflows,
  • Audit-proof regulatory documentation.

Where master data was incomplete or inconsistent, downstream EHS processes were immediately affected.

Hybrid Architecture without Disruption

The side-by-side approach allowed customers to adopt EHS innovations in the Public Cloud without shutting down their existing on-premise environments. This enabled:

  • Gradual modernization instead of big-bang migrations,
  • Reduced transformation risk,
  • Protection of critical operational processes.

From a project perspective, this phased approach proved to be far more controllable than technical full-system replacements.

Standardized Interfaces and Scope Items

Whenever we could rely on standard SAP communication scenarios and scope items, the implantation became significantly faster and more stable. Examples include:

  • SAP_COM_0001, 0008, 0009, 0395
  • EHS scope items such as 3FP (Incident Management), 4XD (Emissions Management), and 54A (Health & Safety Management)

These accelerators reduced custom development effort, simplified testing, and aligned customer landscapes with SAP best practices.

Scalability and Future Readiness

The event-driven and API-first architecture of the Public Cloud supported scalable growth across all projects. Typical examples were:

  • Near real-time updated via SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh,
  • Flexible replication cycles for HR and MDG data,
  • Cloud-native extensibility for future EHS enhancements.

This ensured that the technical foundation remained adaptable as regulatory and sustainability requirements continued to evolve.

Extensibility for Business and Regulatory Needs

Across all customers, extensibility was required mainly for country-specific regulations, additional validations, or customer-specific reporting. In most cases, these requirements could be fulfilled using Key User (In-App) Extensibility, without breaking the clean core. This allowed customers to remain upgrade-stable while still meeting local compliance needs.

2.2 Pitfalls

Despite the strong benefits, several recurring challenges also appeared in almost every project.

System Landscape Complexity

Hybrid landscapes naturally involve multiple systems: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP MDG, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP BTP / Integration Suite. Without clear integration ownership, defined interface responsibilities, and coordinated technical design, landscapes quickly became difficult to operate and monitor.

Dependency on Master Data Quality

EHS processes are extremely sensitive to master data issues. We repeatedly saw how missing materials, outdated organizational requirements, or incorrect functional locations immediately blocked emissions calculations, risk assessments, and incident follow-ups. High master data quality is mandatory.

Custom Development Where Standard Content Is Missing

For some integration scenarios, especially Plant Maintenance integration for Functional Location and Equipment, custom iFlows were still required. This introduced additional development effort, higher testing effort, and long-term maintenance overhead.

Monitoring Challenges

End-to-end monitoring must cover:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud application logs
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise applications logs
  • SAP Master Data Governance application logs
  • SAP SuccessFactors message monitoring
  • SAP Integration Suite / iFlow monitoring

In several projects, missing monitoring initially led to delayed error detection and avoidable compliance risks.

Value Mapping and Harmonization

Incorrect or inconsistent value mappings between systems repeatedly caused replication failures. Early harmonization of organizational units, material types, equipment categories proved to be critical.

Validation of Services and Scope Items

Missing API activations or scope item assignments (e.g., API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION) frequently caused delays late in the project. Early validation of all required services became a key project success factor.

Governance and Limitations of Extensibility

Extensibility offers flexibility but without governance it quickly leads to:

  • Diverging country solutions,
  • Misaligned business logic
  • And long-term technical debt.

Additionally, Developer Extensibility is still limited to released APIs and BAdIs, which means that not every requirement can be solved purely with custom logic.

2.3 Summary of Benefits & Pitfalls

A successful EHS Public Cloud implementation balances the strengths of standardized integration content and clean-core extensibility with disciplined data governance and architectural planning. Organizations that manage this balance effectively can unlock the full potential of SAP EHS – enabling safe, compliant, and scalable EHS operations across the enterprise.

 

3. Outlook

Based on what we observe across current customer projects and SAP’s latest roadmap updates, SAP EHS in the Public Cloud is clearly evolving from a standalone compliance solution toward a central digital backbone for safety, risk, and environmental governance.

Many customers are already productive with core EHS scenarios today. At the same time, the functional scope continues to expand with each Public Cloud release. We see a strong move toward more standardized business content, broader regulatory coverage, and deeper support for environmental and sustainability-driven processes. As a result, future implementations will increasingly rely on configuration rather than custom development which significantly reduces implementation and upgrade effort.

Extensibility will nevertheless remain a key success factor. From our project experience, SAP is steadily increasing both the number and the quality of released APIs and cloud-compliant BAdIs. This allows customers to address local regulatory requirements and  compliant-specific validation logic in a clean-core compatible way. Especially Key User Extensibility is becoming more powerful, enabling business-driven adjustments without technical development.

In parallel, SAP BTP is gaining further importance for advanced EHS use cases. While this blog series focused on On-Stack Extensibility, we already see growing demand for advanced analytics and dashboards, cross-system workflow automation, and IoT-based hazard detection and emissions monitoring. These scenarios clearly go beyond standard transactional processing and position SAP BTP as a natural complement to SAP EHS in complex enterprise landscapes.

Another major trend we observe is the increasing convergence of EHS and sustainability. Environmental compliance, emissions management, and sustainability reporting are becoming tightly connected. From a solution perspective, this strengthens the integration between SAP EHS, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and SAP Sustainability Control Tower. Customers will benefit from more consistent emissions data, integrated compliance reporting, and harmonized master data across production, procurement, and asset management.

For customers, these developments reinforce one central message from our project work: Early architectural discipline pays off. Organizations that invest early in clean-core principles, standardized integration content, high master data quality, and clear extensibility governance are best positioned to benefit from future SAP innovations.

entry.title: Re: How can I to Delete a Subcontracting MRP area?
entry.content:
Hi Jez,

The issue you're experiencing with deleting type 3 (subcontracting) MRP areas is a known problem in S/4HANA systems. The error "It is not allowed to delete MRP areas that are valid" occurs because the system has specific requirements for properly removing subcontracting MRP areas that differ from standard location-based MRP areas.

Root Cause and Solution

This is a documented issue that requires implementing SAP S/4HANA OP2023 FPS2 or applying the correction instruction for SAP S/4HANA OP2023 FPS1 [1]. The problem stems from system validation logic that prevents deletion of subcontracting MRP areas even when all apparent dependencies have been removed.

Step-by-Step Resolution Process

1. Verify System Prerequisites

  • Ensure you're running SAP S/4HANA OP2023 FPS2 or have applied the correction instruction for FPS1
  • Note that there is no correction instruction available for the base SAP S/4HANA OP2023 release [1]

2. Complete Data Cleanup Process

Since you've already performed most cleanup steps, verify the following sequence:

Material Master Cleanup:

  • Set deletion indicators for all MRP area assignments in MM02 [2]
  • Ensure all materials have the deletion flag set specifically for the MRP area view
  • Run transaction MDDIBE to reorganize MRP data
  • Execute report YMRPAREO to clean up remaining MRP area data [2]

Stock and Planning Element Verification:

  • Confirm complete removal of all stock from the subcontracting location
  • Verify no active MRP elements (planned orders, purchase requisitions) reference the MRP area
  • Check for any remaining consumption or forecast data

3. Alternative Approach for Persistent Issues

If the standard cleanup doesn't work, consider this approach based on SAP community recommendations [3]:

  1. Temporarily recreate the MRP area in customizing if it was previously deleted
  2. Re-establish material assignments to the MRP area
  3. Properly set deletion flags for all material assignments
  4. Run YMRPAREO report to systematically remove all dependent data [3]
  5. Attempt deletion through OMIZB again

4. Use Correct Transaction Code

Ensure you're using OMIZB (non-transport relevant) rather than OMIZA for production system changes [4]. OMIZB is specifically designed for local customizing changes without transport requirements.

Important Considerations

Data Safety: The YMRPAREO report permanently deletes MRP area data and should be used with extreme caution. SAP recommends using it only in test systems and assumes no responsibility for side effects [2].

Production Systems: For production environments, ensure you have proper change management procedures in place and consider the impact on ongoing operations.

Advanced Planning Integration: If your materials are marked as Advanced Planning relevant, additional steps may be required to properly phase out the MRP areas from PP/DS planning [5].

** Answer is from "Joule for consultant"

Best regards,

Naveen
